coredata.dc:title: Does green finance investment and technological innovation improve renewable energy efficiency and sustainable development goals
coredata.prism:copyright: Â© 2022 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
coredata.dc:creator: Zhang, Ling
Berk Saydaliev, Hayot
Ma, Xiaoyu
coredata.dc:description: Sustainable goals are achieved by utilizing private firms' investment in renewable energy sources. Globally, the demand for alternative sources of Renewable Energy (RE) and green finance (GF) has prompted an increase in research on these topics. This research applies a novel technique panel cointegration and causality model to evaluate the causes of green finance development in China between 1990 and 2020. This study adds information on the relationship between green finance and financial inclusion in the form of private firms' investments. The findings show that green finance and financial inclusion (FI) are beneficial to development globally and more granular. For every 1% growth in RE sources, there will be a 0.522% rise in trademark filings and a 0.1243% rise in private sector investment filings. The trademark and patent are promoted by 0.062% when financial inclusion is improved by 0.031%. Investment, commerce, and human progress have a calming effect on the connection discussed above. A variety of robustness tests supports our model results. This study's policy recommendations include decentralizing the energy industry to allow for more private sector participation; financial incentives for enterprises to use RE. It is clear from these findings that our study contributes significantly to the field of empirical research and also gives crucial policy recommendations.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Sustainable goals are achieved by utilizing private firms' investment in renewable energy sources. Globally, the demand for alternative sources of Renewable Energy (RE) and green finance (GF) has prompted an increase in research on these topics. This research applies a novel technique panel cointegration and causality model to evaluate the causes of green finance development in China between 1990 and 2020. This study adds information on the relationship between green finance and financial inclusion in the form of private firms' investments. The findings show that green finance and financial inclusion (FI) are beneficial to development globally and more granular. For every 1% growth in RE sources, there will be a 0.522% rise in trademark filings and a 0.1243% rise in private sector investment filings. The trademark and patent are promoted by 0.062% when financial inclusion is improved by 0.031%. Investment, commerce, and human progress have a calming effect on the connection discussed above. A variety of robustness tests supports our model results. This study's policy recommendations include decentralizing the energy industry to allow for more private sector participation; financial incentives for enterprises to use RE. It is clear from these findings that our study contributes significantly to the field of empirical research and also gives crucial policy recommendations.

ce:section.ce:para: The use of renewable sources conserves natural resources by addressing climate change and significantly reduces the need for coal and oil for energy production. According to the Kyoto Protocol and IAEA, most industrialized countries that joined the pact encourage green energy sources [1]. Whether financial growth, the natural environment, and carbon emissions can effectively relieve environmental problems under the paradigm of globalization remains unanswered. Thus, this has demonstrated the financial backing of the theoretical justification by investigating the effects of foreign direct investment, geographical features, globalization, nonrenewable and eco-friendly resource utilization on the contribution to global warming in nations valuable in economic means from 1990 to 2020 [2,3]. According to the empirical results, there is a high correlation between cross-sections. The previous generation panel data technique is used since panel data is more robust and dependable [4]. Over the last 30 years, financial development has remained the dominant and sought-after component of external financing despite the global financial and economic crisis. Foreign direct investment plays a critical role in economic growth [5]. Over the last two decades, there has been a dramatic increase in foreign direct investment (FDI) coming into countries throughout the globe [6].

An increase in the income, output, job growth, economic growth, and progress of the receiving nations directly results from foreign direct investment. Several researchers and politicians believe that foreign direct investment may significantly impact a receiving country's development efforts [7]. Over the years, trade liberalization has emerged as the most important source of international capital inflows to quite developed countries. It has unquestionably become an important aspect of capital creation in these countries, as studied by Ref.Â [8]. As the population continues to increase to nine billion by 2040, it will necessitate an increase of 35% in conventional farming, which will lead to a significant increase in greenhouse gas emissions from the farming sector, where the majority of emissions come from the different industries running for various purposes [9]. Greenhouse gas emissions account for half of the total emissions to limit warming to less than 2Â° Celsius by 2050. As a result of these environmental impacts, attempts to conserve the environment and maintain a manageable level of global warming may be substantially hampered [10].

Low-pollution characteristics aside, sustainable energy's high usage costs need government support and technological development [11]. Consequently, RE consumption can't reach a specific level or serve as an alternative to fossil fuels without the assistance of legislation. As a result, authorities in the OECD's advanced countries began developing relevant laws shortly; Japan, a resource-poor island country, incorporated the sequences to encourage power companies to use a specific amount of new energy. This has made RE a major topic of discussion at international conferences during the last ten years. An overarching concern was finding a method of using fuel to lead to long-term economic growth while also being environmentally friendly [12â16]. As a result, resources seem to be one of the most potential substitutes, and this relationship between ecological sustainability and RE is very strong. Economic growth drives an ever-increasing need for energy, which has clear consequences for the environment [16]. Countries, particularly those in emerging economies, are eager to replace fossil fuels with renewables such as solar and solar thermal to reduce their environmental impact while also slowing down economic development. Customers, companies, and entrepreneurs are the main beneficiaries of economic growth because of the performance and efficiency with which cash can be mobilized and allocated.

Various resources created by technical progress are used by those who benefit from direct investment, significantly influencing energy intensity. They also engage in various additional actions to promote industrialization, trade liberalization, economic expansion, and other factors that may have an indirect impact on green finance [17]. However, the effects on green finance, whether direct or indirect, may change depending on the stage of scientific advancement [18]. For example, the financial sector may not be able to provide customers with as many energy-saving products when technical innovation in the economy is at a lower level, for example. On the other hand, if technological advancement is at a high level, consumers and companies will have access to many energy-consuming items and new chances to employ large numbers of machines that help boost green finance.

Additionally, technical advancements may provide consumers and organizations with resources for finished goods and machinery, minimizing energy use [19]. For this reason, it can be said that the influence of capital accumulation on green finance is caused by technical innovation and is led by scientific progress, whether the latter is encouraging or obstructing. Expanding the financial industry's expertise has necessitated a healthy and well-developed banking sector. However, it also has a tremendous physical influence on economic growth. Reduced investment obstacles and less work on financial resources would increase the trust of both investors and customers in company development and increase the use of substantial subscriptions. It is not inexpensive, though, to reap the benefits of the developing financial industry [18,20], and [21]. Electricity production can be tapped more effectively with a well-developed banking system, and environmental protection can be implemented with little expense and maximal resources [22]. Innumerable research has noted and explored the significant connection between a robust financial system and a deficiency in the environment.

The present research is unique in many ways when the panel cointegration and causality model is used also after monitoring for economic growth, resource, and organizational factors in line with the predictions of neo-classical (partly) and empirical work, we discover a direct and positive influence of RE and GF on FI using unit root test, cross-sectional dependence test, and correlation analysis with fixed effects. These results are not affected by using different sub-samples or estimation methods. Evidence suggests that RE promotes innovation through encouraging investment, human capital, and trade openness, showing the possible routes of RE elevating technical development across various countries. Some empirical research has shown that renewable and efficient energy sources may help boost economic growth and appropriate utilization. Because FI is efficient and economical, some environmental impact may be realized. According to other studies, a lack of knowledge about the most recent advances in sustainable energy innovation can have serious consequences, particularly for rural societiesnear large-scale infrastructure project sites. Consequently, politicians are refocusing their efforts from scientific knowledge to research and innovation. Frameworks of the organizational context have emerged and taken into account various external factors that affect a company's ability to innovate.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Section 2 describes the literature review and hypothesis development. Section 3 contains methodology and data sources. Section 4 consists of results and discussion and robustness analysis. Section 5 presents the conclusion and policy implications.

According to theoretical reasons, FI, RE, and GF all have a role in climate change [23,24]. Empirical research on the importance of financial resources in limiting environmental deterioration among developed nations is lacking. Consequently, the current research aims to address this gap [25â27]. The variables impacting FDI flows to advanced and emerging market economies have been extensively studied. During 1980â2010 [28], found that private investment in G-7 was most likely to occur when the bank's role in green finance was measured by economic output, operating costs, trademark, structural characteristics, real exchange rate, and sustainable development growth.

In contrast, emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) and gross domestic savings were minimal [29]. The only option to slow the rate of environmental deterioration is to switch to a more sustainable form of energy usage. According to Ref.Â [30], since RE cuts carbon footprints, countries must radically reduce their dependence on energy production and invest significantly in sustainable power. Also, they reaffirmed that the best approach to combating ecological damage and global warming is to move from non-renewable materials to renewable resources. According to Ref.Â [31], the transfer between fossil fuels and RE sources is unavoidable if economic development is to be environmentally beneficial [26,32], and [33,34]. The use of renewable power was also condemned by Ref.Â [34], who praised the requirement to create and spread RE to slow down the rate of warming.

The authors of [35] items and Hotaling also emphasized the need to rapidly shift to energy sources that are either renewable, greener, or much less dangerous while still promoting economic development. In the meantime while, the sustainability of green finance is dependent on the faith that private sector investment has in it to attain the desired aim [36]. If an asset's current price reflects its historical information, then additional knowledge will prompt a swift increase in the price, bringing the asset's true worth closer to its market valuation [37]. Shareholders, financial advisers, and the administration are at risk of unleveraged vulnerabilities when business statements are not linked. Green finance might be eroded to support ordinary interest rates and other formal economic markets. As a result, the green finance market's potential to guide the global economy toward ecological sustainability may be weakened. Because tackling climate change is an increasing concern among stakeholders, firms have tried to improve their corporate reputation by openly adopting sustainability problems without good content to back such "green" assertions about environmental maintenance [38]. Entrepreneurs, policymakers, and consumers all affect sustainable development accounting policies. Investors will be influenced by the effectiveness of such financial accounting and explanations if they are of poor quality. Others allege that organizations are engaging in a practice known as "green finance" by inflating their"ideology assertions" about performance measurement via their disclosure practices [39].

According to Ref.Â [28], integrating financial inclusion, private investment, and non-financial information into green finance can be a comfortable way to highlight and sustain RE in a new way to counter the adverse effects generated by the ongoing scenario around the world. "The validated model to associate disclosed information with shareholder necessities and offer additional precise data," he writes. "It facilitates better choices, reduces costs, and enhances regulatory compliance." Furthermore, these "complete system structures are typically" facilitated by these unsupervised Comprehensive Accounts [40]. Decision-makers' verification and assessment are unavoidable if an integrated organizational report is more effective.

The [41] Energy Strategy states that green finance and financial inclusion are critical to establishing a more efficient, safe, and low carbon economy [42]. The UK government's efforts to improve international competitiveness include GF [43]. Towards ecological sustainability [44], proposes that solar technology growth in G-20 nations may have a multiplier effect on economic advancement. As a result of this phenomenon, countries [44] concluded that increasing RE would improve the sustainability of the environment. According to Ref.Â [45], the advantages of RE production outweigh the costs for families. According to Ref.Â [46], there is no link between renewable fuel use and sustainable development in low, medium, and high-income countries.

There is a strong link between RE, green finance, and financial inclusion. According to several different theories, financial inclusion is necessary for a country's overall economic development. The economically affected, the majority of whom are mostly impoverished and illiterate, benefit greatly from the ability to save and track their financial transactions via the use of a financial institution. It allows them to get financing and invest in new businesses. Such firms enable people to earn more money than if they worked for a low-paying job [47]. Lenders might enhance the effectiveness of money for financing by relaxing credit rules for this group. As a result, the nation's economic investment was reduced, contributing to higher overall growth [48]. Increased accessibility to interest rates and lines of credit has a positive impact on newer areas of the state. It helps lenders diversify their portfolios, decrease risk, increase lending, and contribute to the economy's overall development [49]. By increasing borrowing from private sector participation, Green finance makes credit risk more efficient as a significant instrument [50]. Financial inclusion's influence on green finance has received little empirical attention in the past [51], but this analysis adds to the available sparse work.

The impact of RE on human resources is the last critical connection between green finance and financial inclusion. Increasing living standards, improving access to quality, and guaranteeing that all civilizations have equal and fair access to RE sources are just a few ways that energy may produce positive outcomes for growth. Financial inclusion is a major asset for the sector's growth in the era of knowledge by processing information and converting it into production. For instance, research shows that the cost of generating new products is directly proportional to the number of creative people engaged in doing so [52]. Private sector participation, in turn, is essential to the success of financial inclusion.

On the other hand, green finance enhances total factor productivity by seeking to make external and domestic capital more desirable. A sustainable approach for all life depends on a GF that utilizes RE sources to produce goods and services. Using FI sources to create GF may help combat climate change pollutants while protecting human well-being from harmful air pollutants. For example [53], for instance, claims GF aids in the preservation of natural areas and resources while also enhancing human well-being and addressing human needs. RE positively influences human capital development, but fossil fuels negatively affect [54]. As stated by Ref.Â [55], it protects against neurodegeneration, breathing problems, malignancies, and heart problems.

Using G-20 (HDI) data [56], found that increasing access to RE sources substantially impacts the human development report. RE sources provide greater promise than other methods of mitigating climate change [57]. RE benefits include reduced greenhouse gas emissions, increased life expectancy, and lower healthcare costs, according to Ref.Â [58]. According to the [59], HDI in rural areas may be improved by employing excellent energy supplies and clean fuels locally available. To our knowledge, this is the first study to examine the potential of RE to reduce pollution and improve human well-being. Because of this, the availability of energy is a key component of pleasure. A wide range of benefits may be gained from RE, including increased access to nutritious foods, job creation, and reduced health concerns. Increased economic efficiency and research and development as a major component of manufacturing are two of the many benefits of making the energy industry more efficient via green finance (GF). To put things into perspective, GF boosts the potential of nations to innovate through improving trade openness, overall investment, and private sector participation. From the other perspective, output variables such as skilled labor, money, and financial inclusion may impact efficiency via these three channels. GF and FI are shown to be linked in theory. Consequently, we arrive at the following second hypothesis on RE and private sector investment.

Green finance is promoted by finance, commerce, business, and entrepreneurship in RE. It is possible to explore the link between economic development and energy use by utilizing four propositions. First, there's the idea that the amount of energy we use affects how fast the economy grows. However, previous research has mainly focused on finding the cause-and-effect relationship between GF and FI, with little or no regard for how GF and FI might affect RE. According to this theory, energy conservation has a negative impact on economic development since it reveals a one-way relationship between energy use and income.

On the other hand, the environmental protection hypothesis establishes a one-way monetary policy and energy use [60,61]. Lower efficiency used to show significantly affect financial development. The input argument suggests that economic development and green finance are linked in a negative feedback loop, showing that efficiency negatively impacts financial development and energy consumption. As a result, the feedback hypothesis indicated a two-way causality between increases in production and increased energy use. Furthermore, the nondiscrimination theory does not demonstrate a causal relationship between economic growth and green finance use. It also indicates that reducing one's energy usage has no impact on economic development [62â65].

We found that the recent Covid-19 epidemic disrupted most global economic and financial operations and those in China, which was the first country to be infected and was the most severely impacted. Our findings align with previous research and the study's stated goals. It is also worth noting that China is the world's largest importer of energy and the second-largest emitter of CO2. Therefore, it is critical to look into Chinese green finance investment and technological innovation to improve RE efficiency and sustainable development goals. The function of green finance in technological innovation has been extensively studied. Green finance and technological innovation are linked in a two-way interaction known as the " Renewable Energy Efficiency and Sustainable Development Goals."The previous studies exaggerated Green Finance as a predictor of economic development, which failed to consider its influence. Green finance is important to many other studies, and they claim that it may affect long-term growth rates by affecting saving rates, investment choices, and technological innovation. Many more studies support this claim. The financial industry can quickly identify the most promising new developments by focusing on technical initiatives with a high likelihood of success. In addition, the financial services business collects individual savings and makes it easier to make better use of those funds, which improves resource allocation and spurs technical innovation. Green finance has a favorable effect on economic development regardless of the country's bank or stock market structure. However, developing nations have a hurdle since a lack of financial development might prevent them from reaping the advantages of technological transfers that could help them flourish. It is believed that green finance would positively influence sustainable development since finance is projected to contribute to technological innovation. In light of past research, this effect is achieved via various pathways. RE may be used to achieve sustainable economic development because non-renewable energy use leads to unregulated environmental deterioration and diminishment of natural capital, argues that it is unsustainable.

RE, a range of factors, such as the growth of renewable energy technology, consumption of fossil fuels, ecological sustainability, and energy independence, has led to worldwide investments in natural energy conversion. Because fossil fuels have been nearing extinction and their emissions have skyrocketed in the 21st century, renewables have become more important. The utilization of RE sources is expanding at an alarming rate. Climate change, structural stability, and ecological health adversely affect our reliance on nonrenewable energy sources. According to the United Nations, one of the most serious global issues is how to produce and effectively use energy that comes from clean energy sources.

Green finance, a recent study by Ref.Â [77], analyses the average share values of green finance indexes to learn about the liquidity of the green bond market. Macroeconomic studies show that RE, green finance, and financial inclusion are linked. There must be a goal to increase energy availability and consumption to achieve environmental sustainability. That's why authorities must work to make energy more readily available while also limiting its harm to people's environment and public health. In addition, a more efficient allocation of private sector investment and cleaner energy resources to maintain economic growth. We conducted empirical research to understand better how RE and green finance impact financial inclusion. According to trademark and private sector participants, RE and green finance positively impact innovation when ecological, economic, and organizational aspects are taken. The findings show that RE policies drive the development of complementary technologies.

On the other hand, the policy has a varying influence on the scale of the impact on various aspects of financial inclusion. As RE usage increases by one percent, trademark and private sector participation increase by 0.1243%, 0.279%, and 0.437%, respectively. In comparison, patent applications increase by 0.275%, 0.151%, and 0.114% in countries with stricter RE legislation. Improving energy efficiency also helps trademarks, patents, and other intellectual property rights by 0.036%, 0.029%, and 0.054%, respectively.

The ways in which RE may aid in the growth of green finance. As a result of RE, capital, commerce, and human capital have a greater influence on financial inclusion. The RE multiplier impact on capital has further benefits for new statistical applications for development. Statistically significant, it positively affects trademarks and private sector investment in related technological fields. It also encourages the development of new RE -complementing technologies thanks to trade openness. Expanding the number of trademarks and patents on alternative energy sources is necessary if nations implement a nationwide clean RE policy. As evidenced by improved business and human-friendly sustainability rates in countries with strong renewable policy initiatives, RE appears to offer spillover effects for fostering innovation. As a result, economic stimulation, trade openness, and human resource development are all boosted when using RE sources. We obtained comparable results using two-stage least squares, fixed-effect Poisson regression with fixed effect, and system extended moment technique. We used the sub-sample method to make sure our estimates were solid.

For policies that promote financial inclusion and incorporate new renewable sources to achieve a deep transition to a low-carbon economy, our results offer a variety of policy implications. Because measures are required to green finance efficiency and sustainable development, aside from concentrating on topics that directly impact RE, authorities should also join the hunt for additional methods to ensure long-term advancements in financial inclusion and private sector investment. According to the report, RE regulations positively impact human economic growth, commerce, and capital, promoting organizational effectiveness.
I.
The administration should push businesses in major industrial countries to engage more RE sources for technological advancement. These incentives and financial incentives may also achieve this objective.
II.
For private sector activities to reduce technical expenses, an economic incentive for new RE research should be available by purchasing costs. Even if these additional expenses to the price of electricity, the impact of handouts will be greater.
III.
There should be more government support for RE while tackling environmental challenges. Because of this, these measures may help foster development and long-term economic growth.
IV.
As a result of abundant and inexpensive renewable resources, new alternative energy sources will be more widely adopted, supporting more advanced energy technology growth and usage.
V.
Governments must ensure that prices can compete and laws are well-enforced.
VI.
Green finance and sustainable activities should be promoted by businesses and consumers alike via the implementation of climate change policy and other environmental safeguards.
VII.
Presenting countries on the resource supply market with tradable and domain registrars.
VIII.
Carbon taxation, closed-loop control tariffs, and renewable electricity constraints should be adopted to promote fossil fuel use. Increased demand for RE will motivate corporations to switch from fossil fuels.
IX.
It is time for countries to move their energy needs away from conventional renewable resources and toward RE generation to foster innovation. As a result, different countries and regions have different aims for RE policy and development, such as energy security and economic strategies. There are several ways in which RE helps to stimulate growth, from fundamental technological advancements to better basic research and installation methods to better market procedures for industrialization and entrepreneurship. When it comes to encouraging improvement, countries must have the right policies and institutions.
